title: How many new energy vehicles (NEVs) will be sold in China in 2020?
preds: Wish I paid more attention to this one. https://www.argusmedia.com/en/news/2168144-chinas-januarynovember-nev-sales-rise

I'm going all in: total 1,310,000 give or take 30K. 
Why? In every one of the last four years sales in December have exceeded those of November, and I can't see any indicator to suggest a major upset.

I’m going to be even more bullish on Chinese economic growth for December. Chinese stock went higher lifted by strong continued recovery signals in November  Also. I’ll share the latest stats to prove the trajectory later today https://sg.finance.yahoo.com/news/asia-pacific-shares-mostly-higher-124234164.html

I realize the measurement is caam but slightly different numbers here (Nov not provided yet). regardless bumping up fifth bucket as I’m completely unsure of any year end impacts (pro or con). I really can’t tell on this one. 
https://www.statista.com/statistics/425458/china-monthly-new-energy-vehicle-sales-by-type/

November data adds 200K units for a total for the year of 1.1M units.
Add an estimated 200K for December to yield 1.3M units for the year filling the last bucket.
If only 150K units are sold in December it would be right on the bubble.
Since I was all in on the fourth bucket before, I'll need to go all in on the fifth bucket to have a shot at this one.

Numbers may be off slightly but believe ~890 through Oct. a couple decent mints easy gets to  1 100 - 1 250. June through Oct has seen 104, 98, 98, 138, 160... so a decent (as seems very likely) Nov will provide solid indicator.

Thru Sept 734K NEVs sold. 
Thru Oct 901K NEVs sold. 
 Simple extrapolation yields 1.22M units by year end. 
GAME OVER

I think total will be very close to 1,100,000. Everything points towards China pushing ahead with production and sales now they are out of the first Covid-19 wave.  
I'm hedging slightly against earlier forecasts just under this break point.

I think the big question has now become whether the sales will exceed 1,100,000. Volumes look to be highest in the last quarter of each year, as a general trend over the last few years. And they increased noticeably over September from approx 100K/m over summer. If the last three months report similar levels we could be right on the break point. Overall there seems more likelihood of a downside than up, so I'm cautiously staying at around 1,080,000
NEV sales are accelerating from previous quarter. Could be near 1.1M units this year.

The numbers coming out exceeded my (prior) thoughts. Pushing 750 with 1/4 of year left. Points to something in 970-980 range even accounting for year end. Plus supply/demand increasing (not decreasing). Not sure how to factor increases. Regardless per others something close to 1 million
Thru Sept 734K NEVs sold. Simple extrapolation yields 978K units by year end. 1M units really looks achievable.

Based on the existing production and sales in Sep, Oct - Dec is likely to follow a similar trend, giving more weight to the nearer month sales, a range of 1 million to 1.15 is likely. Additional news based on Xi's commitment to climate change, this increases the likelihood where the political agenda improves the numbers.
Same view as from August 10th, as sales have picked up in the latter half of the year.

I'm still anticipating a 10-20% drop from 2019. I think the second half of this year will see similar figures to 2019, compared to a 30-40% drop in the first half. Continuing subsidies should help, along with the gradual trend away from fossil fuels, increasing climate concerns, and China's desire to keep manufacturing developing. Offset perhaps by cheaper oil prices and economic uncertainty.

I'm still anticipating a 10-20% drop from 2019 overall. I think the second half of this year will see similar figures to last years, making up somewhat for 3-40% drop in the first half. Continuing subsidies should help, along with the inexorable trend away from fossil fuels and greater climate concerns, offset perhaps by cheaper oil prices and economic uncertainty.

Adjusting my forecast to a narrower band. Outside of major distortions (second waves, natural disasters), China's EV market is right on track to cross the 950,000. Finally found a way to visualize why in this link: https://deviantlookingdata.com/predicting-new-energy-vehicles-sales-in-china-for-2020/

Sales slowed by Covid-19, recovering, but perhaps not a quickly as we'd like.
Bloomberg 9/11 - "While the Shanghai plant has helped Tesla grow in China this year, it hasn’t expanded as quickly as some expected. The company has said it has the capacity to produce 200,000 vehicles a year -- almost 17,000 a month -- and in August sold about 11,800 cars in the country."

Yoy is at 19.3 for july with overall Yoy at -32.8 now. This is a faster recovery than I expected after seeing the numbers for june. Unsure how much weight to give this as it might be an outlier, given the decline even in 2019 before the coronavirus was a thing. Forecast: 3|15|66|15|1. Crowd: 6|44|44|6|0
Corrected forecast: 3|18|65|13|1
I'll take an optimistic view. NEV's are good for the planet and government policy encourages them. And who wants public transport at this time?
Expecting roughly 10-15% drop based on reduced sales for first half of year

YoY sales have gone down rather than up in june compared to may from -23.5 to -33.1. Still this represents a slight overall recovery to -37.4 of last years production.  2019, roughly half of sales happened in the first half of the year. 
Brackets in percentage relative to last year:  67|79|92|104
YoY growth for the next half year to reach these: -28.6|-4.6|21.4|45.4 The last two brackets are not going to happen. The second to last one also seems quite unlikely given the lack of recovery in the june numbers. The june numbers also make me update a bit towards the first bracket from the second one, even though I still believe that some kind of recovery to a decline of less than 28% is more likely for the rest of the year.

According to the CAAM portal, production and sales of NEVs stand at 400,000. Currently it is catching up at 20%. However, the overall projection is 30% negative growth. 
Hence, at 10% growth rate, it may be above 800,000 and 20% growth, it can reach upto 1,200,000.

Last two years (2018 & 2019) it was 1.2-1.3mln new sales. I project a restart of the 2020 economy in 2021, so sales growth to resume or to at least sales to flatten out at previous years’ levels (i.e. of ~1.2mln). I will therefore split probability between more than 1.25mln, and 1.1-1.25mln, with more weight to the higher bracket. I still leave some space for reduced sales, possibly due to a persistently soft economy.
Sales volume reduction due to COVID-19 related sales drop

Hat tip to @V-Y- and the data from technode. Total NEV sales in 2020 would contract, but by how much is the question. Earlier estimates by the automotive industry was looking at a 15%-25% decline on overall vehicle sales, but now they feel that overall vehicle sales would decline by 15% ONLY.  A similar drop in NEV sales would lead to 1,020,000 NEV sales.
The Chinese will uptake electric vehicles due to the external pressures of retaliation over COVID-19
I can't say just yet, but it feels like our consensus is off. Tesla is expanding and just about everyone is getting in the game. Maybe I'm wrong.

According to the source cited in https://technode.com/2020/06/16/ev-industry-grapples-with-consensus-as-sales-fall-further-in-may/, https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/Hm8YWA0MQNznxCeiiVmepQ we have a drop of 23.5% to 82000, while there was a drop of 38.7% to 289.000 for the january to may time frame.  This gives us total sales of around 734500 for june to december 2019.  Scenario one: most of the drop was due to covid 19, as supported by the smaller drop in May. Sales will slowly recover to previous years sales by the end of the year. Assuming linear recovery for simplicity, this would lead to a 11.75% drop compared to last year, giving us 655541+289000 = 944541 sales. 
Scenario one.a : As before, but with a 23.5% yty increase by the end of the year (giving us the same number as last year with linear recovery):  289000+734500=1023500 Obviously, a faster recovery could change the numbers quite a bit, here. 
Scenario two: the 23.5% decrease is maintained over the rest of the year, due to economic downturn or any other underlying factors that contributed to the previous decline. This would yield around 851000 sales. 
Scenario three: larger outbreaks of covid, or larger long-term effects on the economy than I expect lead to a decline of around 35% for the rest of the year, which gives us 766425 sales. Brackets in terms of percentage decline for the rest of the year: 
-30%|-11%|10%|30% Forecast without seeing crowd: 20|66|12|2|0
Crowd: 68|26|6|0|0 
Updated forecast: 25|65|9|1|0 (rather small update, as I expect most crowd forecasts to have used less up-to date/detailed data)

Thanks to @V-Y- and @bobrown for their comments + provided sources [1,2,3]. From the in [3] linked Chinese source [4] (translated using deepl): "4. new energy vehicles continue to decline year-over-year In May, the production and sales of new energy vehicles finished 84,000 and 82,000 units respectively, down 25.8% and 23.5% year-on-year. The production and sales of electric vehicles were completed in May, down 25.8% and 23.5% respectively year-on-year. The production and sales of pure electric vehicles were completed by 63,000 and 64,000 vehicles respectively, down 33.8 per cent and 25.1 per cent year-on-year. The production and sales of plug-in hybrid vehicles were completed at 21,000 and 18,000 units respectively, with production up 17.1% and sales up 17.1% year-on-year. Down 16.1% year-on-year; fuel cell vehicle production and sales completed 17 and 42 units, down 94.6% and 94.6% respectively year-on-year. 86.7%.
From January to May, the production and sales of new energy vehicles completed 295,000 and 289,000 units respectively, down 39.7% and 38.7%. The production and sales of pure electric vehicles finished at 222,000 units, down 42.8% and 39.8% respectively year-on-year; plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles were also down 38.7%. The production and sales of power vehicles completed 72,000 and 67,000 units respectively, down 27.5 per cent and 35.0 per cent year-on-year. The production and sales of fuel cell vehicles completed 309 and 322 units respectively, down 44.1% and 40.9% year-on-year." [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1077006
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1076827
[3] https://technode.com/2020/06/16/ev-industry-grapples-with-consensus-as-sales-fall-further-in-may/
[4] https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/Hm8YWA0MQNznxCeiiVmepQ

Baseline was a bell curve around middle option  (950-1,100k), simply downgrading from 1.2m because last year is negatively impacted by COVID This article for June shows even the "bearish" analysts estimate are  still 1m+ vehicles. My hypothesis is that the government is biased to support this sector as a future "Growth Engine", and will provide incentives to keep momentum https://technode.com/2020/06/16/ev-industry-grapples-with-consensus-as-sales-fall-further-in-may/

2019 sales were 1.2M without Chinese built TSLA's. While 2020 may be a slower year due to Covid impact on finances those who can afford may be eager to avoid public transport. Locally built TSLA's should also drive nation wide sales higher. Hedging for future impact of Covid-19 in China and on demand for Chinese exports.
